Amanda N Heath Horn
September 6 at 6:00 PM ·

Update on Nate...

There is a small amount of blood in one of the creases in his brain that is causing the limited use of his left arm (which frustrates him terribly). His vision is blurry, another frustration. Doctors are hoping that blood will absorb soon. We’re still in ICU. He has slept most of the day.

His labs came back. His hemoglobin is 6.9 and his platelets are at 80. Blood doctors are looking towards a red blood cell transfusion....

Still a waiting game- his brain has to be healthy enough in order to begin the next phase of testing. Testing to figure out why all this happened. Doctors have a really good hunch as mentioned yesterday, but the bone marrow test has not been done- looking for that maybe later on in the week.

Thank you, again. I’m hearing from people from North Carolina to California. And the special favors called in to this place.... astounding. ❤️

Amanda N Heath Horn
September 5 at 9:36 PM ·

Update on Nate Pike #9

Grant, one of the guys who took Nate and me in the helicopter, just stopped by.
Nate doesn’t understand the progress he has made, but Grant started to explain Nate’s status from last night to tonight....
Then Nate lifted his left arm, and Grant said, “Hell yeah!!” Grant continued to explain that last night Nate couldn’t even wiggle his toes on his left foot while in transit. Grant was very enthusiastic about the change in a 24 hour period.
He’s making progress. He feels like it is little, but Jody and I see that it is much larger. Right now, Nate is alert and more like himself. His headache is really bad though.
Your prayers are working. Thank you for rallying around this wonderful young man.

It is that time again! We ask each year and we are blessed each year when individuals and families donate HHS memorabilia for our school archives and museum display. These awesome photos are from Chad Parker (Class of 2007) but they belonged to his grandad. There is lots more to go through but these stood out immediately. His grandad graduated in 1950 (yes, we have his diplomas from Handley Elementary, Handley Jr High, and Handley High . If you have HHS items that you know will just go to the trash heap one day, please consider donating them. The Community Studies class has gotten a $1500 grant to properly store these items and protect them for 100s of years. If you want your HHS memorabilia to live on and be learning tools for future Handley History Labs, we’d love to add them to our repository.

August 9 at 11:23 AM ·

"My best advice to any nursing student would be to find joy throughout the process. There will be days that overwhelm you and test your diligence, but stick with it! It is worth it and you are SO capable! Enjoy the good days and experiences; remember you are human and you do not have to be perfect. Try your hardest at each test, but don't stress yourself out over it. You can and will finish your degree! Never forget why you started and why you want to finish. For study tips: record in class lectures and/or go back to online lectures and listen while you study. I like to write down extra notes while doing this. It also helps me to make "study sheets" of the main points, things that I find important, and things that I may need to review again. Practicing NCLEX style questions helps, as well!"

The Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE) has partnered with the University of Alabama to conduct a statewide school technology survey. The purpose of this survey is to build a statewide repository detailing Internet connectivity and Internet-enabled digital device availability to inform decision-makers as we expand remote learning capabilities and enhance high-quality instruction to students around the state.
Whether a student is attending school in a traditional classroom setting, virtually, or a blended version of traditional and virtual, it is important that we hear from parents across the state as the survey responses will impact our efforts to respond to ongoing changes relating to remote and blended learning options throughout our state. The deadline for completing the survey is Friday, July 31, 2020. The link is below.
